Award.AwardTitle: Mentoring and Networking Workshop for Junior Women Faculty in the Big 10

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Very few opportunities exist for junior women faculty in engineering to network, foster peer mentoring relationships, and interact with other female engineering faculty, particularly with female role models. The difficulty in connecting junior women faculty with senior women mentors contributes to under-representation of women in engineering faculty. The proposed workshop for assistant professors is designed to provide them with professional skills that will help them be successful faculty members and give them opportunities for mentorship and professional collaborations across institutions to counter isolation and lack of networking opportunities.

The goal of this workshop is to enhance the professional skills and network of junior women faculty in engineering departments in the Big 10+. Methods used will include faculty toolbox sessions to provide core skills (negotiation, elevator pitch, management skills), activities designed to build peer-mentoring skills, and a professional coaching session. A keynote speaker and a panel session with deans from the Big 10+ will provide participants the perspectives of senior administrative leaders. In addition, a panel will address the intersection of race and gender in a session during the meeting. The senior women mentors who attend will also benefit from additional mentoring training, mentoring experience, and development of their own research networks.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
There are few opportunities for junior women faculty in engineering to network, foster peer mentoring relationships and interact with other female engineering faculty. The Big 10 Women’s Workshop was designed for women assistant professors from engineering departments who were in the first three years of their academic appointments at a Big 10 School. Senior faculty representatives from the schools were also involved as faculty mentors. The workshop proposed to provide a professional networking opportunity, cultivation of peer collaborations and mentoring relationships, and foster interactions with senior faculty.  The most recent offering of the workshop was March 23-24, 2016. Forty-nine junior women faculty and 16 senior faculty attended the workshop. Attendees valued greatly the keynote address and skill building events (faculty toolbox sessions on negotiation strategies and building management skills in faculty).  Roughly 30% of the participants identified as underrepresented minorities. The session on the intersection of race, gender and engineering was highly valued by all participants and comments from both majority and underrepresented participants expressed appreciation for insights gained from the session.  Other population activities included the peer mentoring sessions and the Dean’s panel. The workshop remains an important professional development opportunity for junior female faculty in engineering departments and there are plans to continue to offer it.
